page.title: List of Old Boys of Sydney Boys High School

revisions.rev:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2007}} This is a '''List Old Boys of Sydney Boys High School''', they being notable former students - known as "Old Boys" of the [[Selective school (New South Wales)|academically selective]], [[Sydney Boys High School]] in [[Moore Park, New South Wales|Moore Park]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]].
In 2001, ''[[The Sun-Herald]]'' ranked Sydney Boys High School fifth in Australia's top ten schools for boys, based on the number of its [[alumni]] mentioned in the ''[[Who's Who in Australia]]'' (a listing of notable Australians).<ref name=WhosWho>{{cite news| first = Frank| last = Walker| title = The ties that bind| url = http://newsstore.smh.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?page=1&sy=smh&kw=%22presbyterian+ladies+college%22&pb=all_ffx&dt=selectRange&dr=entire&so=relevance&sf=author&sf=headline&sf=text&rc=10&rm=200&sp=nrm&clsPage=1&docID=SHD01072295GNI6E8E6E| work = Sunday Life| publisher = The Sun-Herald| page = 16| date = 2001-07-22| accessdate = 2007-09-12}}</ref>
<!-- Please add alumni in alphabetical order under appropriate category (Rhodes Scholars excluded) -->
==Business== * [[RenÃ© Rivkin]] — stockbroker * [[John McGrath]] — founder of McGrath Real Estate Agency
==Entertainment, media and the arts== * [[Bruce Beaver]]— award-winning poet. * [[Richard Bonynge]] — conductor of the [[Vancouver Opera]], married [[Dame Joan Sutherland]] (opera singer) * [[Russell Crowe]] — actor * [[Glenn Fraser]] — filmmaker * [[Richard Grossman (musician)|Rick Grossman]] — bass guitarist ([[Matt Finish]], [[Divinyls]], [[Hoodoo Gurus]] and [[Ghostwriters]]) * [[John Kingsmill]] — author and actor * [[George Levendis]] — [[Music executive|Record executive]] * [[Daniel MacPherson]] — actor and television presentor * [[Mondo Rock|Eric McCusker]] — guitarist and songwriter * [[George Miller (producer)|George Miller]] — director (''[[Happy Feet (film)|Happy Feet]]'', ''[[Mad Max]]'', ''[[Babe (film)|Babe]]) * [[John Prior (musician)|John Prior]] — drummer ([[Matt Finish]]) * [[John Stanley (radio broadcaster)]] — radio presenter of [[2UE]] * [[Jack Thompson (actor)|Jack Thompson]], [[Order of Australia|AM]] — actor * [[Danny Weidler]] — sports journalist for [[Network Nine]] and [[The Sun-Herald]] * [[Nic Testoni]] — actor [[Home and Away]] * Gregory Fine; TV Producer * [[Ilan Kidron]] — singer, songwriter [[The Potbelleez]]
== Medicine and science == * [[Ronald N. Bracewell]] — Lewis M. Terman Professor of Electrical Engineering, Emeritus of the Space, Telecommunications and Radioscience Laboratory at [[Stanford University]] * [[Graeme Clark (doctor)|Graeme Milbourne Clark]] [[Companions of the Order of Australia|AC]] [[Order of Australia|AO]] — pioneer of the multiple-channel [[cochlear implant]]; founder of the Bionic Ear Institute; [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] * Professor [[John Cornforth]] — [[Nobel Prize|Nobel Laureate]] for Chemistry (1975) * Lord [[Robert May, Baron May of Oxford|Robert May of Oxford]] — former [[Presidents of the Royal Society|President]] of the [[Royal Society]], [[Chief Scientific Adviser to the UK Government]] (1995-2000) * Emeritus Professor [[Hans Freeman|Hans Charles Freeman]] [[Order of Australia|AM]] [[Australian Academy of Science|FAA]] — [[metalloprotein]] crystallographer and bio-inorganic chemist who established and developed the field of [[crystallography]] in Australia * Sir [[Grafton Elliot Smith]] — [[anatomist]]
== Politics, public service and the law == * Sir [[Arthur Roden Cutler|Roden Cutler]], [[Victoria Cross|VC]] [[Order of Australia|AK]] [[Order of St Michael and St George|KCMG]] [[Royal Victorian Order|KCVO]] [[Order of British Empire|CBE]] — longest serving [[NSW]] State [[Governor of New South Wales|Governor]] (1966-1981)<ref name=ARCutler>{{cite web|url= http://www.warmemorialsnsw.asn.au/traditions/cutler.cfm|title= Sir (Arthur) Roden Cutler|accessdate= 2008-01-23 |year= 2008|work= Register of War Memorials in New South Wales|publisher= New South Wales Government }}</ref> * Hon. [[Marcus Einfeld]] — retired judge of the [[Federal Court of Australia]] and former President of the [[Australian Human Rights Commission|Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission]] * Professor [[David Flint]] — head of the [[Australian Broadcasting Authority]] (1997-2004) * [[Ian Glachan]] — State Member for [[Electoral district of Albury|Albury]], served as [[Justice of the Peace]] * Hon. [[Harold Glass]] [[Order of Australia|AO]] [[Rear Admiral|RFD]] — former Justice of the Court of Appeal and Judge Advocate General for the [[Royal Australian Navy]] * [[Ted Mack (politician)|Ted Mack]] — Mayor of North Sydney (1980-1988), State Member for [[Electoral district of North Shore|North Shore]] (1981-1988), Federal Member for [[Division of North Sydney|North Sydney]] (1990-1996) * [[Scott Morrison (politician)|Scott Morrison]] — Federal Member for [[Division of Cook|Cook]] * Hon. [[Lionel Murphy]] — Justice of the [[High Court of Australia]] (1975-1986) * Sir [[Earle Page]] — [[Prime Minister of Australia]] (1939) * [[Paul Pearce]] — State Member for [[Electoral district of Coogee|Coogee]], former Mayor of [[Waverley Municipal Council|Waverley]] * Hon. [[Nye Perram]] — judge of the [[Federal Court of Australia]] * [[John Pilger]] — journalist and documentary film-maker * [[James Plimsoll|Sir James Plimsoll]] — diplomat and [[Governor of Tasmania]] * Hon. [[Jim Spigelman]] — Chief Justice of the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales]] (1998- ) * [[Nicholas Whitlam]] — son of Prime Minister [[Gough Whitlam]]; Chief Executive of the [[State Bank of New South Wales]] * [[Tony Whitlam]] — son of Prime Minister [[Gough Whitlam]]; MHR [[Australian Labor Party|(ALP)]] (1975-1977) * [[James Wolfensohn]] — President of the [[World Bank Group|World Bank]] (1995-2005)
==[[Rhodes Scholars]]== * 1919 - [[Arthur Wesley Wheen]] — BA [[University of Sydney]] (completed University of Oxford)
== Sport == * [[Frank Row]] — rugby-union player (first [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallaby]] captain) * [[John Thornett]] — rugby union player (63 time [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallaby]] captain, 1962-67) * [[John Brass]] — dual rugby-code international (former [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallaby]], [[Australia national rugby league team|Kangaroo]] & [[Australia national rugby league team|Kangaroo]] captain) * [[Chris Whitaker]] — rugby union player ([[NSW Waratahs|Waratahs]], [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallaby]] captain) * [[Jason Jones-Hughes]] — rugby union player ([[Randwick DRUFC|Randwick]], [[NSW Waratahs|Waratahs]], [[Newport RFC|Newport]], [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]) * [[Marc Stcherbina]] — rugby union player ([[NSW Waratahs|Waratahs]], Australian Rugby Sevens) * [[Craig Wing]] — rugby league player ([[South Sydney Rabbitohs]], [[New South Wales Rugby League team|NSW Blues]], [[Australia national rugby league team|Australia]]) * [[Bob Dwyer]] — World Cup-winning rugby union coach ([[Australia national rugby union team|Wallabies]]) * [[Alan Gaffney]] — former assistant and backs coach ([[Australia national rugby union team|Wallabies]]) * [[Jack Metcalfe]] — athlete, [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] medalist and twice [[Commonwealth Games]] champion in [[Triple Jump]] * [[Jamie Morgan]] — tennis player ([[Davis Cup]]) * [[Sam Robson]] — cricket player for Middlesex county cricket club * [[Dominic Grimm]] — world champion in the coxed pair rowing 2011
